Its graphics were tremendous but quickly surpassed by next-gen games\, and the gameplay wasn't something groundbreaking.The biggest reason was the story.A dad loses his daughter\, loses hope for years\, until he gets a straight forward mission to help an innocent girl. Both of them embark on an adventure and explore the world at the same time as the audience/gamers. Eventually\, both of them became emotional towards each other. At this point\, the audience/gamers see them as a father and a daughter. When the time comes for the finale\, the man is put in a similar situation to the beginning\, where he is about to lose the girl like he lost his daughter\, but this time he couldn't let that happen again. So he helps her—cycle complete.With The Last of Us Part II\, the story has taken a backseat\, without a spoiler it is all about revenge. And it is not even a good revenge story. So all the game is left with is Good graphics and decent gameplay. Both of which are not enough to play through the kind of damage you'll receive for loving the characters in the first game.
